Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlord-tenant law)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlor.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord holds an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential tenancy. That implied covenant guarantees that the tenant will have quiet possession and reasonable use of the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s authority. See, e.g., Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (general landlord-tenant law); Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §12.1 (implied covenant of quiet enjoyment); see also general common-law authorities recognizing the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment and landlord obligations are recognized in Massachusetts and may be enforced by tenants in court. See, e.g., Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (statutory framework governing tenancies and landlord-tenant relations); 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation); see also Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §12.1 et seq. (implied covenant of quiet enjoyment).

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Massachusetts C.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Massachusetts Consumer Protection Act) — (recognition that unfair practices by landlords may give rise to statutory claims in appropriate cases; cited as background authority for landlord duties and tenant remedies).
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Massachusetts C.proposition:
Relevant authorities include, by way of example and not limitation:

- Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (Landlord and Tenant statutes).
- Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 93A (Massachusetts Consumer Protection Act) — (recognition that unfair practices by landlords may give rise to statutory claims in appropriate cases; cited as background authority for landlord duties and tenant remedies).
- 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (State Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation).
- Restatement (Second) of Property: Landlord & Tenant §12.1 (implied covenant of quiet enjoyment).
- Restatement (Second) of Torts §§821B–821C (private nuisance principles as analogous authority for interference claims).

Jones v. John Doe (Mass. App. Ct.).raw_text: Jones v. John Doe (Mass. App. Ct.)
Jones v. John Doe (Mass. App. Ct.).proposition: Courts in Massachusetts and elsewhere have held that landlords may be liable for substantial interference with quiet enjoyment caused by construction, nuisance, or other recurring disturbances, and that tenants may recover damages or other relief.
